chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Any reform should keep the country’s federal character while making the presidency track the will of voters more closely and reducing the outsized power of a few battleground states. A practical middle path is to keep the Electoral College but require states to move away from winner-take-all—through proportional allocation or a uniform “popular-vote winner gets electors” compact—with clear, nationwide rules for recount triggers, certification timelines, and ballot transparency. Pairing that with a higher threshold to win (or a ranked-choice runoff) can ensure the winner has broad support and help more Americans accept the result.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: The Electoral College should be kept but reformed so the winner more consistently reflects the national will while preserving meaningful regional voice. A strong compromise is to end winner-take-all by requiring proportional (or district-based) allocation of electors, or to adopt the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact with clear, uniform recount and certification rules. Pair any change with baseline national standards for ballot access, transparent audits, and secure vote handling so every lawful vote is treated equally and outcomes are easier to trust across urban, suburban, and rural communities.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: A fair compromise is to keep the Electoral College framework but reduce winner-take-all so most states award electors proportionally (or with a simple statewide-plus-district split) to make every vote matter more and broaden where campaigns compete. If the country moves toward a national popular vote through the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact, it should include clear recount triggers, consistent certification timelines, and a transparent audit process so close elections don’t become nationwide chaos. Across any reform, agree on baseline national standards for ballot access and counting—set by law and applied evenly—while leaving day-to-day administration to states so both big-city voters and smaller communities trust the result.
